results.title: The Thermal wilderness (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Illustrates the necessary precautions to be taken when hiking in hot and heat-wave conditions. Shows ways to avoid complications due to salt depletion, heat cramp, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the basic tgreatment for these conditions.
Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: The Themes of Macbeth
results.creator_credit: John Barnes, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Douglas Campbell
results.brief_description: Studies how the play Macbeth is built on the paradox. “Nothing is but what is not”. Explains that the world of Macbeth is one in which appearances cannot be trusted. Narrated by Douglas Campbell.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Barnes, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Douglas Campbell

results.title: The Theatres of the sun: Seaport at Sunset (1639), Claude Lorrain 1602-1682
results.creator_credit: Alain Jaubert, Delta Image, Musée du Louvre, FR3 and La Sept
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Palettes”.
Claude Lorrain’s painting “Seaport at sunset” is one of a pair of paintings. The colours, the spacing of the figures, the lighting close to the ground and the perspective of the buildings converge to produce an illusion of depth. This program examines the painting in detail, at Claude Lorrain’s life and the historical setting in which he lived, the symbolism of the painting and his technique, which ultimately led to Turner and impressionism.

results.title: The Thames: Royal Windsor to Tilbury
results.creator_credit: Millicent Walker and John C. Walker
results.brief_description: The River Thames has been called “England’s liquid history”. It starts in the Cotswold Hills and winds for over 160 miles, through nine English counties until it reaches London. In the journey downstream, beginning at Windsor Castle, Eton, Datchet, Staines, Walton-on-Thames, Hampton Court Palace, Richmond Hill, Kew Gardens, and so on to London, and Battersea Park, the Tate Gallery, Lambeth Palace, the Houses of Parliament, Tower Bridge, Greenwich and finally, Tilbury Docks are shown.

results.title: The Texture of light: The Astronomer (1668) Johannes Vermeer
results.creator_credit: Alain Jaubert, Les Films d'Ici, Delta Image, FR3 and La Sept
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Palettes”.
A detailed look at Vermeer’s painting “The Astronomer” and its companion piece “The Geographer” in the context of the entire body of Vermeer’s work, which is not large. These extraordinarily detailed portraits, all apparently set in the same interior, show a photographic vision, aided perhaps by the use of the camera obscura, and an acute awareness of the properties of light. Explores Vermeer’s technique and the possible symbolism of the paintings’ props.
results.title_for_label: The Texture of light: The Astronomer (1668) Johannes Vermeer

results.title: The Textile touch
results.creator_credit: Cyril Bursell, McCurdy-Bursell Films and Jim McCurdy
results.brief_description: Macrame, rug-hooking and loom weaving are three rewarding techniques of expressing creativity with textiles. The film gives art students a solid introduction to these textile techniques and encourages them towards freedom from the constraints of traditional designs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cyril Bursell, McCurdy-Bursell Films and Jim McCurdy

results.title: The Texas chainsaw massacre = The Texas chain saw massacre
results.brief_description: Loosely based on the grizzly exploits of American serial killer Ed Gein (also a model for Norman Bates in “Psycho”), Tobe Hooper’s “The Texas chain saw massacre” rightly deserves its place as a horror classic. Five teenagers travelling through Texas (two of them brother and sister investigating the mysterious desecration of their grandfather’s grave), pick up a creepy hitchhiker and find themselves embroiled in a macabre and nightmarish reverse of southern hospitality. From its eerie opening images to its shocking finale, “The Texas chain saw massacre’ was initially considered a cheap drive-in exploitation film but, through strong critical appraisal, went on to be screened as part of the director’s fortnight at Cannes and the American Museum of Modern Art now has a print of it in its permanent collection. Cast includes Marilyn Burns, Allen Danziger and Gunnar Hansen as Leatherface. Please note: special features are contained on disk two.
